answers: NMDA receptors [or N-methyl-D-aspartate receptors] and AMPA receptors [or α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid receptors]
Arc [or activity-regulated cytoskeleton associated protein] <Science - Biology>
parts: Name this generic term which refers to the brain’s ability to permanently change and reorganize itself, frequently via the strengthening and weakening of synapses.

Synaptic plasticity is largely regulated by the activity of these two types of ion channels. Along with the kainate receptor, these two receptors allow the neurotransmitter glutamate to alter the balance of cations inside and outside of nerve cells. Name both.

This plasticity protein in the “immediate early gene” family serves as a regulator of synaptic strength. Its generic-sounding name references the dependency of its localization to the synapse on microtubule-associated transport and actin-dependent docking.
Name this chemist and historian. In his many-volume history of science in China, this man asked why China fell behind Europe despite an early technological advantage, his namesake “question.”

Mark Elvin’s answer to the Needham Question in part cites a shift in elite culture from Daoism to this other Chinese belief system. Chinese civil servants took torturous exams that forced them to recite passages from this system’s Five Classics.
This University of Chicago historian sought to synthesize ecological, geographic, and economic causes to explain the Needham question in his seminal work, The Great Divergence.
Name this golden-colored creature. The narrator, Antonio, begins to turn away from Catholicism after Samuel tells him a myth about it.
Antonio learns about the golden carp in this 1972 Rudolfo Anaya novel, in which he is mentored by the title elderly healer.

Throughout the novel, Antonio is comforted by this animal, which is spiritually linked to Ultima and dies when she dies. While protecting Ultima from an attack, it savagely gouges out one of Tenorio’s eyes.
Give this two-word English-language term for an unofficial policy that was banned by a 1945 directive, which held that this practice contributed to nationalism and militarism during World War II.

This intellectual movement, whose name means “native studies,” began during the Tokugawa period as an attempt to remove Chinese influences from traditional Japanese religion. Moto·ori Norinaga contributed to this movement with his complete analysis of the Kojiki.

Though freedom of religion is enshrined in Japan’s postwar constitution, politicians like Junichirō Koizumi have made visits to this Shinto shrine that honors Japan’s war dead, including many convicted war criminals.

answers: Frederick Douglass [or Frederick Augustus Washington Bailey]
parts: Name this man who also gave lectures titled “Age of Pictures,” “Life Pictures,” and “Pictures and Progress.” Many photographs of him were preserved in albums collected by Arabella Chapman.

Frederick Douglass, who’s done an amazing job and is being recognized more and more, saw photography as a counterpoint to minstrelsy, which he denounced often in essays for this newspaper that he edited from 1847 to 1851.
Douglass invoked the example of white viewers confronting a photograph of this Mississippi senator, the first African American to serve in either house of Congress.

answers: Jean Paul [or Johann Paul Friedrich Richter; or Jean Paul Richter]
parts: Name this early German Romantic novelist who used a French pseudonym. The twins Walt and Vult in his unfinished novel The Awkward Age inspired Robert Schumann’s personas Florestan and Eusebius.
Critics like Friedrich Schlegel often compared Jean Paul’s digressive novels to the books of this Irish-born author, who became a European celebrity after writing Tristram Shandy.

This German author loved Sterne, and considered him equal to Shakespeare. A blistering polemic by Karl Kraus blames this man for infecting German literature with the “feuilleton” [foy-TAWN] after his 1831 flight from Germany to Paris.

answers: Etta [accept Jamesetta, which was Etta James’s real first name]
parts: Name this man who helped create the “Blue Note Sound” at his namesake Studio in New Jersey. A remaster series called his namesake “edition” includes albums like Blue Train and Somethin’ Else.

Van Gelder recorded Don’t Go to Strangers and many other albums for a singer with this first name and surname Jones. A jazz and soul singer with this first name recorded the song “At Last” for Chess Records.

In 1957, Van Gelder became one of the first to embrace this recording technology, which required the use of two-track tape. This technology was finally adopted fully by the Beatles in 1968 for the White Album.

answers: iso·thio·cyanate [or ITC; accept FITC; accept phenyl iso·thio·cyanate; do not accept or prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this phenomenon that underlies dyes like rhodamine and SYBR Green. Osamu Shimomura purified a protein which displays this phenomenon, allowing it to be used as a reporter for gene expression.

The dye fluorescein is frequently derivatized with this functional group, which is responsible for the pungency of wasabi and horseradish. When benzene is substituted with this functional group, it forms a reagent used to sequence proteins in the Edman degradation.

These probes for qPCR consist of a synthetic hairpin-shaped oligonucleotide with a fluorophore at the 5-prime end and a quencher at the 3-prime end. When they bind to a target sequence, they unfold, moving the quencher away from the fluorophore.

answers: Mapuche [or, I suppose, the Araucanians if you’re an EVIL IMPERIALIST]
parts: Name this man whose heart, according to an epic poem by Alonso de Ercilla, was removed and passed around like a hot potato on the orders of Caupolicán, one of several toqui chiefs this man battled.

Pedro de Valdivia supposedly cut the toes off of an invading force of these people at El Valle de la Mocha, where they were led by Lautaro. These winners at the Battle of Tucapel retained independence to the Bio Bio river throughout the entire colonial era.
Before his heart problems, Pedro de Valdivia served as a lieutenant under this man, who executed his most famous foe after capturing him at Cajamarca.

answers: Chupa Chups logo [accept answers referring to Chupa Chups lollipops]
Salvador Dalí [or Salvador Domingo Felipe Jacinto Dalí i Domènech]
parts: Identify this piece of commercial art produced at the request of the Catalan candy magnate Enric Bernat. It consists of a yellow, eight-petaled daisy outline surrounding two cursive words in red.
This artist designed the Chupa Chups logo in 1969, 15 years after he painted The Disintegration of his own painting The Persistence of Memory.
This Franco-American “Father of Industrial Design” created classic logos for Hoover, Exxon, Shell, and Nabisco, among many others.

answers: WebAssembly [or Wasm; do not accept or prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this open standard for frontend development that allows browser applications to be compiled into a more efficient binary encoding. It was first released as a minimum viable product in 2017.

Like its namesake, WebAssembly uses an architecture based on “sets” of these statements, allowing execution by an in-browser virtual machine. Interpreters convert program statements to these statements in machine code.

WebAssembly’s support for LLVM languages makes it viable for use with this language, the “most loved” by Stack Overflow users every year since 2016. This language invented by Mozilla borrows traits from Haskell and uses the keywords match and let, but it’s perhaps best known for its property of “fearless concurrency.”

answers: Suleiman the Magnificent [or Suleiman I; or Kanuni Sultan Suleyman; or Soliman]
parts: Voltaire claimed that “nothing is better known” than what event, where the great commander Dragut was killed by a cannonball while trying to cut off Fort St. Elmo from Fort St. Angelo?
Voltaire’s original quote goes on to claim that the siege checked the fortunes of this Ottoman sultan, whose forces besieged Vienna in 1527.

The siege was resisted by the Knights Hospitaller, an order originally founded by a “blessed” Benedictine with this name. This is also the surname of a man who had his skin slowly pincered off as punishment for a murder committed while the victim was talking to Welsh commander Roger Williams.

answers: hospitality [or hospes; accept Of Hospitality] <Social Science>
parts: Name this orientalist scholar, who, in 1786 posited connections between Sanskrit and western languages such as Latin, which developed into the theory of Proto-Indo-European.

Languages of the Indo-European family are divided into two groups largely based on their pronunciation of the word with this meaning, based on whether the initial consonant merged with the plain velar.

Emile Beneveniste’s work on the shared Indo-European roots of the words for “hostility” and this other word for the practice of receiving a guest with goodwill, influenced a 2000 book by Jacques Derrida.

answers: male gaze [do not accept or prompt on putative synonyms]
parts: Name this Tunisian-French filmmaker, who became the first director to win a Palme d’Or alongside his lead actors for 2013’s Blue Is the Warmest Colour, starring Adèle Exarchopoulos and Léa Seydoux.

The long, gratuitous sex scenes in Kechiche’s films have been deemed exemplars of this two-word term. Laura Mulvey’s “Visual Pleasure and Narrative Cinema” coined this term for the scopophilic depiction of women by men.
The most recent instalment of Kechiche’s Mektoub, My Love trilogy has this subtitle. Ingrid Bergman’s Hollywood debut was as a violinist’s lover in a 1939 David O. Selznick film with this title.
Name this proponent of New Criticism, who collected his essays in books like Hateful Contraries and The Verbal Icon.

Wimsatt collaborated with Monroe Beardsley to write essays arguing that these two critical fallacies result in “biography and relativism.” They defined one of them as “a confusion between the poem and its results,” and the other as “a confusion between the poem and its origins.”

Another New Critic, Cleanth Brooks, analyzed this author’s poem “The Canonization” in his essay “The Well-Wrought Urn.” T.S. Eliot’s essay “The Metaphysical Poets” praises this author’s “unified sensibility” of thought and feeling.

Name this city where modern medical instruction was pioneered by Herman Boerhaave. This institution’s famed Hortus Botanicus was located next to an observatory built to house Rudolph Snellius’s great quadrant.

Leiden was home to one of Europe’s first “theaters” for observing this practice central to empirical anatomical learning. Nicolaes Tulp, who was instructed at Leiden, was painted carrying out this type of instruction by Rembrandt.

Boerhaave was the teacher of this man, who revolutionized medicine in the Habsburg empire while serving as Maria Theresa’s personal doctor. To his considerable aggravation, this man was dispatched to solve a local vampire problem in Serbia after the Treaty of Passarowitz brought Balkan lands into the Habsburg domain.

answers: Mulla Sadra [or Sadr ad-Dīn Muhammad Shīrāzī] <Philosophy>
parts: Name this mystical school of Islamic philosophy founded by the twelfth-century Persian thinker Suhrawardi. It is based on the principle of sufficient reason and the Aristotelian injunction against actual infinities.
Suhrawardi translated this philosopher’s work Treatise of the Bird into Persian, although he opposed this man’s Peripatetic views. This man also wrote an encyclopedia called the Canon of Medicine.
This seventeenth-century Persian philosopher, considered the master of illuminationist philosophy, described a doctrine of existence in his best-known work, Four Journeys.

answers: AUMF [or Authorization for (the) Use of Military Force (Against Terrorists)]
Hamdan v. Rumsfeld [prompt on Rumsfeld; do not accept “Hamdi,” which is a different case] <Modern World>
parts: Essentially the entire War on Terror has been justified through a 2001 example of what sort of Congressional resolution, the only way the President can exceed the limits of the War Powers Resolution without a formal declaration of war?
The only member of Congress to vote against the AUMF, Barbara Lee, continues to represent this state in the House of Representatives. Nancy Pelosi also represents this state.

The Supreme Court held that the language of the AUMF did not authorize the President to convene military tribunals in contravention of the Geneva Accords and the Uniform Code of Military Justice in this 2006 case. It was brought by a Yemeni bodyguard of Osama bin Laden.

answers: boundary of the first Brillouin zone [accept edge of the first Brillouin zone; do not accept or prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name these vibrational modes, which are in-phase displacements of atoms in a crystal lattice.
At this point, the frequency of an acoustic phonon reaches a maximum value of 2 times the square root of the spring constant divided by mass.

The resistivity of metals is linear in this quantity, due to the interaction between electrons and phonons. In the denominator of the exponential term of the Arrhenius equation, the gas constant R multiplies this intensive quantity, measured in Kelvin.

answers: Miles Franklin [or Stella Maria Sarah Miles Franklin] <Literature - Other/World>
parts: Name this ethnicity of the activist author Kevin Gilbert. An author with this ethnicity, who changed her name from Kath Walker, described a “semi-naked band subdued and silent” who feel like strangers in a “little town” in her poem “We are Going.”
This author controversially depicted a murder spree by an indigenous Australian in his novel The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith. He won the Booker Prize for his novel Schindler’s Ark.
In 2007, the second novel by indigenous Australian author Alexis Wright, Carpentaria, won the most prestigious Australian literary award, which is named for this author of My Brilliant Career.
